abstract.text: A number of charmonium-(bottmonium-)like states have been observed in B-factory experiments. Recently the BESIII experiment has joined this search with a unique data sample collected at the different center of mass energies ranging from 3.9 GeV to 4.42 GeV in which they found new charmonium-like states with non-zero electric charge. We review the status of experimental searchs for quarkomonium-like states and also other types of non-qq meson or non-qqq baryons that are predicted by QCD-motivated models. We mainly focus on results from the B-factories and BESIII.

body_text.text: Introduction

Mesons and baryons are formed from color-singlet combinations of quarks. All nonqq mesons and non-qqq baryons predicted by QCD-motivated models are expected to be in color-singlet multi-quark combinations.

Color-singlet multiquark states can be formed from colored diquarks and diantiquarks: a pentaquark is predicted to contain two diquarks and one antiquark, the H-dibaryon contains three diquarks, and tetraquark mesons contain a diquark and diantiquark. Multiquark states can also be formed by molecules of two (or more) color-singlet qq mesons and/or qqq baryons that are bound together by the exchange of virtual π σ, ω, etc. mesons. In this way, Pentaquarks, the H-dibaryon, baryonium and tetraquark mesons can be formed. If these exist, where are they ?
Pentaquark

A pentaquark is a predicted baryonic bound state of four quarks and one antiquark. In the 2003, two experiments, LEPS and CLAS, reported the existence of a positive strangeness baryon that they called the Θ + . After that, a number of experiments reported the observation of confirming signals and even other new types of pentaquarks. But later, high-statistices experiments 1,2 with higher statistics could not reproduce these signals suggesting that the LEPS-CLAS results were due to statistical effects rather than a real resonance. Therefore the existence of the pentaquark is still an open question.
The H-dibaryon

The possibility of a six-quark state was first proposed by R.L. Jaffe in 1977. 3 He dubbed it the H-dibaryon, and prdicted it to have a strangeness=−2 and baryon number=+2. Such a state could possibly be either a tightly bound diquark triplet or a hyperon-hyperon molecular type state. Jaffe's original prediction was 0 + dihyperon with the mass that is about 80 MeV below the 2m Λ threshold. His original specific prediction was ruled out by observation of a double-Λ hypernuclei events. Especially the "NAGARA" event 4 observed in double-Λ hypernuclei, 6 ΛΛ He, which greatly narrowed the mass window of the H to be M H > 2m Λ -B ΛΛ MeV, with binding energy B ΛΛ = 7.25 ± 0.19 +0.18 −0.11 , corresponding to a lower limit of the H mass to be 2223.7MeV/c 2 .

Although Jaffe's original prediction for B H ∼80 MeV has been ruled out, the theoretical case for an H-dibaryon with a mass near 2m Λ remains concrete. Recent Lattice QCD results indicate the existence of an H-dibaryon with the mass close to the 2m Λ threshold 5 and this motivated a Belle search for the H near the mass of the 2m Λ threshold. For an H mass below 2m Λ threshold, the H would decay via a ∆S = 1 weak-interaction with a number of possible decay channels: Λpπ, λ n, Σ p, and Σn. For an H mass above the 2Λ threshold and below the mass of Ξp, the H would decay stongly into ΛΛ almost 100% of the time.

Belle searched for the H-dibaryon production in inclusive Υ(1, 2S) → HX; H → Λpπ − and ΛΛ process using data sample containing 102 million events of Υ(1S) and 158 million events of Υ(2S) collected with Belle detector operating at the KEKB e + e − collider. The dominant decay mechanism for the narrow Υ(nS) resonances (n=1,2 and 3) is annihilation into three gluons. Each gluon materializes as quark-antiquark pairs and, since the Υ states are flavor SU(3) singlets, uū, dd and ss pairs are produced in nearly equal numbers. This strangeness-rich highdensity quark environment in a limited volume of phase space is ideal for producing multi-quark hadron states, especially S = −2, H-dibaryon.

These Υ(1, 2S) decays are a rich source of 6-quark antideuteron production, as demonstrated by large branching fraction of ∼ 3 × 10 −5 measured by the AR-GUS and CLEO experiments. 6 The physics of near-threshold S-wave Feshbach resonances ensure that an H-dibaryon in this mass region should be very similar in character to a ΛΛ version of the deuteron. Moreover, since the Υ(1S) and Υ(2S) are Flavor-SU(3) singlets, S= −2 counterparts of the antideuteron should be produced with sensitivities below or at the rate for antideuteron production.

The Fig. 1 shows results from the Belle search for H-dibaryon masses below and above the 2m Λ threshold. 7 For masses below threshold (left), the H is searched for as a peak in the Λpπ    horizontal dotted line. No evidence was found for a signal in any of these modes, and the most stringent branching-fraction upper limits on H-dibaryon production are determined for masses near the 2m Λ threshold.
Candidate of baryonium

Ten years ago, the BESII experiment reported the observation of a peculiar threshold enhancement in the pp invariant mass distribution in the radiative decay process J/ψ → γpp using 58M J/ψ events. 8 A fit to the enhancement in the M (pp) distribution near the M = 2m p mass threshold with an S-wave Breit-Wigner function gave a below threshold peak value of M =1859 +3 −10 (stat) +5 −25 (syst) MeV/c 2 and an upper limit on the full width of Γ <30 MeV at the 90% CL. The enhancement could not be explained by final state interactions (FSI) between the p andp and there was no corresponding any known resonance states listed in the standard table that could account for this state.

With (225.2 ± 2.8) × 10 6 J/ψ events sample collected with the BESIII detector, a partial wave analysis that included I = 0 FSI between p andp gave a mass and upper limit on the width of M = 1832 +19 +18 −5 −17 ± 19(model) MeV/c 2 and Γ <76 MeV at the 90% CL. 9 The fitted mass peak is about 40 MeV below the M = 2m p mass threshold. Also the γ polar angle and pp decay angle distributions favor the J P C = 0 −+ quantum number assignment over any other possibility with statistical significances that are larger than 6.8σ.

One proposed interpretation for this enhancement is that it is baryonium, i.e. a deuteron-like proton-antiproton bound state produced by standard nuclear forces mediated by π, σ and/or ω exchanges. For such a state with mass below the 2m p mass threshold, the p andp would annihilate to mesons, while above threshold it would be expected to "fall apart" to pp final states almost 100% of the time. Since pp annihilation to π + π − η ′ or 3(π + π − ) are common and dominant channels for I =0, J P C = 0 −+ pp annihilations searches for the same state in the radiative processes J/ψ → γπ + π − η ′ and J/ψ → γ3(π + π − ) were pursued by BESIII with the same J/ψ data sample.

A dramatic peak was seen in the M (π + π − η ′ ) spectrum 10 at M = 1837 ± 3 +5 −3 MeV/c 2 , very similar to the one measured from pp mass, also the cosine of the γ polar angle distribution is consistent with the form of 0 −+ . Although the mass and J pc are consistent with those in the pp channel, the broad width (Γ = 190 ± 9 +38 −36 MeV) is not. Two more new states at higher masses, dubbed X(2120) and X(2370), are also observed in the same M (π + π − η ′ ) mass distribution. Recently, BESIII reported the results of a study of the radiative process J/ψ → γ3(π + π − ), where a clear peak near 2m p was seen with mass M = 1842.2 ± 4.2 +7.1 −2.6 MeV/c 2 and width Γ = 83 ± 14 ± 11 MeV, 11 consistent with the the pp values. Are these peaks observed in the pp, ππη ′ and 3π + π − mass distribution all from the same state? The masses are consistent with each other, but the width measured from pp is significantly narrower than the width of the π + π − η ′ enhancement. These reso-nances could come from different sources or there may be more than one resonance contributing to the ππη ′ peak. To clarify all these, further study is needed including the measurement of J pc for the X(1842) → 3(π + π − ) signal.

The XY Z quarkonium-like mesons

The XY Z states are known as states that decay into final states containing a cc (or bb) quark pair but do not fit into the conventional charmonium (bottomonium) spectrum. The X(3872), a key member of this family, was first discovered as a peak in the π + π − J/ψ mass by Belle 18 in the B → π + π − J/ψK decay process and confirmed by four different experiments and observed via five different decay channels. The quantum numbers were unambiguously determined to be J P C = 1 ++ by the LHCb experiment 19 by an analysis of the B → X(3872)K; X(3872) → π + π − J/ψ decay chain. This result favors an exotic explanation of the X(3872) state and disfavors a simple cc charmonium assignment. Recently, one more production channel was observed by BESIII 20 , where a 6.3σ significance X(3872) signal is reported in the process e + e − → γX(3872) using data collected at the four center γX(3872) are seen at √ s = 4.229 and 4.260, while cross section at √ s = 4.009 and 4.360 GeV were consistent with zero. This suggests the X(3872) might be produced from the radiative transition of the Y (4260) rather than from the ψ(4040) or Y (4360), but, with the current limited statistics, continuum production cannot be ruled out.

The charged charmonium-like state Z(4430) + , as a controversal member, was first observed by Belle 21,22 as a peak in the π + ψ ′ mass in B → Kπ + ψ ′ decays. However, the search by BaBar didn't confirm this signal. 23 . Belle also observed two more charged states, Z + 1 and Z + 2 , that are seen in the final states π + χ c1 in the exclusive B → Kπ + χ c1 decays. 24 Recently Belle has reported the measurement of quantum numbers of the Z(4430) + by performing a full amplitude analysis of B 0 → ψ ′ K + π − in four dimensions. The table 1 shows the results from 4-D fit, the preferred spin-parity hypotheses is 1 + , which is favored over 0 − by 2.9σ, but 0 − also cannot be ruled out with current statistics. 25 The Y (4260) is a J P C =1 −− resonance peak that was discovered in the e + e − → π + π − J/ψ cross section by BaBar. 26 It was subsequently confirmed by CLEO 28 , Belle 29 and BESII. 30 A remarkable feature of the Y (4260) is its large partial width of Γ(Y (4260) → π + π − J/ψ) >1 MeV which is much larger than that for typical charmonium. 31 This motivated the Belle to investigate whether or not there is a corresponding structure in the bottomonium mass region. This study found that there is a large anomalous cross section for e + e − → π + π − Υ(nS) (n=1,2,3) for e + e − cm energies around 10.9 GeV, near the Υ(5S) resonance. 32 Belle subsequently found that Υ(5S) decays to π + π − Υ(nS) final states are strong sources of charged, bottomonium-like states of Z b (10610) and Z b (10650). We started these Υ(5S) mass region search to see Y (4260) analogy in b quark sector. Then we found two charged bottomonium-like states which are the smoking guns for non qq mesons, then the next questions are " are there c-quark versions of Z b s ?". The answer is followed in the next section.
The bottomonium-like mesons
The charmonium-like mesons

Search for new states were mostly confined to analyses of B-factory data including Belle and BaBar, now it has been expanded to include investigations of Y (4260) and Y (4360) resonance decays using data from BESIII. BESIII/BEPCII(Beijing Electron Positron Collider) has been operating as a Y factory for the past six months, collecting large data samples of e + e − annihilation events at 13 different CM energies from 3.9 GeV to 4.42 GeV, 37 especially, at the peaks of the Y (4230) (1090.0 pb −1 ), Y (4260) (826.8 pb −1 ) and the Y (4360) ( 5 pb −1 ) resonances, allowing in-depth studies for the decay properties of these states.

Previous studies of these resonances were done at the B-factories using the radiative return process, which provides rather low luminosities in the charm threshold region. After this conference, BESIII reported the observation of this charged state at one more decay channel: e + e − → π ± (DD * ) ∓ at the center of mass energy of 4.26 GeV using 525 pb −1 data 40 . A distinct charged structure is observed near the threshold of m(D) + m(D * ± ) in the (DD * ) ∓ mass distribution, at M = (3883.9 ± 1.5 ± 4.2)M eV /c 2 , which is 2σ and 1σ, respectively, below those of the Z c → π ± J/ψ peak observed by BESIII and Belle. Here the large Z c signal yield permitted the establishment of the J P quantum number of the πZ c system to be 1 + . Summary

The J P C =1 −− Y (4260) and Υ(5S) have no compelling interpretations. The Y (4260) (Υ(5S)) has huge couplings to π + π − J/ψ (π + π − Υ(nS)) that were not predicted in any model, and are strong sources of charged Z c (Z b ) states observed at π ± J/ψ, π ± h c (π ± Υ(nS), π ± h b ) mass, and also with mass near m(D ( * ) )+m(D * ) (m(B ( * ) )+ m(B * )).

Numerous nonqq mesons not specific to QCD have been found, such as a baryonium candidate in J/ψ → γpp at BESII and BESIII and XY Z mesons that contains cc and bb pairs together with light quarks ud or uū.

QCD motivated spectroscopies predicted by theorists do not seem to exist. No evidence was found for Pentaquarks, and an Hdibaryon with mass near 2m Λ is excluded at stringent levels. No hint on D ++ s0 isospin partner state of D + s0 (2317) is observed.

Doubly charged partner states of D + s0 (2317) The D + s0 (2317), hereafter referred to as the D + s0 was first observed by BaBar 12 as a narrow peak in the D + s0 π 0 mass spectrum produced in e + e − annihilation to D + s0 π 0 +X process and subsequently confirmed by CLEO 13 and Belle. Its production in B meson decay were also established by both Belle 14 and BaBar 15 . It is generally considered to be the conventional I(J p ) = 0(0 + ) p-wave cs meson, but its mass M D + s0 = 2317.8 ± 0.6 MeV/c 2 41 is very similar as the one M D * 0 = 2318 ± 29 MeV of the non-strange 0 + P-wave D * 0 state, in spite of the mass difference between the s and u (or d) quarks which is known as m s − m u(d) ∼ 100 MeV. Furthermore, Potential model and lattice QCD published prior to its discovery all predicted 0 + Pwave cs meson mass to be well above the m D 0 + m K + = 2358.6 MeV threshold with a large partial decay width for D + s0 → DK. Two charged bottomonium-like states, the Z b (10610) and Z b (10650), have been observed in the π ± Υ(nS) and π ± h b (mS) mass at Belle experiment in the decay process Υ(10860) → π + π − Υ(nS) (n = 1,2,3) and π + π − h b (mP ) (m = 1,2).33 Since they have non-zero electric charge, they must contain a minimum of four quarks.The mass of the Z b (10610) is +(2.7 ± 2.1) MeV above the M B + M * B threshold mass, while the Z b (10650) is +(2.0 ± 1.8) MeV above the 2M * B . The proximity to the BB * and B * B * threshold mass suggest that these Z b states may be a molecular type state formed by two mesons. This interpretaion can be checked by studying the Z b → BB * and Z b → B * B * in the Υ → πB(B * )B * three body decay. 34Figure 4shows two distinct peaks at the masses of Z b (10610) and Z b (10650). In this fit the mass was fixed to the earlier measurements. This three body decay analysis is extended to Υ(10860) → Υ(nS)π + π − and Υ(10860) → h b π + π − to measure not only the newly observed Z b states but also the fractions of individual contribution to the whole three-body signals.
